goal: Close semantic anchoring chain: Brunschwig recipes -> Product types -> A entry MIDDLEs
conclusion: MIDDLEs encode operational state constraints, not material compatibility

phase1_ab_flow.question: Do A folios classified by product type feed B folios in matching REGIMEs?
phase1_ab_flow.interpretation: A->B flow via MIDDLE overlap is essentially random

phase2_discriminating_middles.question: Are product-type MIDDLEs disjoint?
phase2_discriminating_middles.interpretation: Top-10 discriminators are disjoint but overall exclusivity is marginal

phase3_material_incompatibility.question: Does MIDDLE incompatibility align with material processing incompatibility?
phase3_material_incompatibility.interpretation: Weak directional signal, but insufficient for semantic anchoring

phase4_entry_prediction.question: Can we predict product type from entry structure?
phase4_entry_prediction.interpretation: Discriminating MIDDLEs too rare for entry-level prediction

key_findings: A and B have 77.4% non-overlapping MIDDLE vocabularies
Top-10 discriminating MIDDLEs are 100% disjoint across product types
Cross-product incompatibility is 7.7% higher than self-incompatibility
Only 2.7% of A entries contain discriminating MIDDLEs
Entry-level prediction accuracy is essentially random (28.9% vs 25% baseline)

constraints_validated.name: Zero Material Encoding
constraints_validated.extension: Confirmed at entry level - MIDDLEs do not encode material identity

updated_interpretation: MIDDLEs encode operational state constraints (what configurations are allowed, what transitions are legal) rather than material compatibility. The Brunschwig alignment is valid at the procedural level but does not provide a semantic anchor to real-world substances.
